script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, most people read the story of Adam and Eve's Fall as a heartbreaking tragedy—they lose paradise and face pain and death. But what if I told you that after being cast out of Eden, Adam and Eve were glad? How could that be?

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's the mystery at the heart of Genesis 3 and Moses 4-5, Sarah. In Moses 5:10-11, after an angel teaches them about sacrifice and redemption, they rejoice, saying, 'we know nothing about God; nevertheless you have made it known unto us.' This shifts everything from loss to possibility.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wait, glad to leave the Garden? That's fascinating. Tell me more about why the Fall was actually important to God's plan.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly, the Come, Follow Me introduction explains that leaving Eden was the necessary first step for growth. Adam and Eve needed opposition, choices, mistakes, repentance, and the Savior's Atonement to progress and find 'the joy of our redemption,' as Moses 5:11 puts it.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: So from the ancient Israelite view in Genesis 3, it looks like punishment, but the restored view in Moses reveals purpose. That's a powerful multi-perspective shift. How does opposition fit into this?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Spot on. In Moses 4:1-4, we see Heavenly Father and Jesus protecting agency against Satan's plan to destroy it. Lehi echoes this in 2 Nephi 2:11-13, teaching 'opposition in all things' is essential—no growth without it.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love how Lehi connects back to Adam and Eve. Notice this pattern: the Fall introduces opposition, which enables agency across dispensations. What happens next in their story?

script.speaker: David
script.text: After the Fall in Moses 4:22-31, they face toil, pain, and separation, mirroring Genesis 3:16-19. But then in Moses 5:4-15, an angel reveals God's redemption plan—they learn of Christ and are glad.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's remarkable. So the results of the Fall affect us all, but Jesus offers hope right away. How did they respond?

script.speaker: David
script.text: They offered sacrifices in Moses 5:5-8, symbolizing Christ's Atonement. Abel's willing heart was accepted, unlike Cain's in Moses 5:16-26. This pattern of obedient sacrifice points straight to the Savior.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Hold on, sacrifices right after the Fall? That's a direct link to Jesus. What about the clothing part—Genesis 3:21 says God made coats of skins for them.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, Moses 4:13-16, 27 shows they first tried covering themselves with fig leaves, but God clothed them. Symbolically, clothing represents covenants and protection, like in Revelation 7:9, 13-15 or temple garments.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I never saw the clothing as pointing to temple covenants before. That's a hidden connection most people miss. How does this tie to Satan's role?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Satan tempted them in Moses 4:4-12, seeking to deceive and blind, just as he did their children in Moses 5:13-33. He uses the same tactics today—questioning God's word, promising godlike knowledge without consequences.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: True, and God helps us resist through agency and His plan. Now, here's where it gets powerful for marriages—Genesis 3:16 about Adam ruling over Eve.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Often misunderstood, but prophets clarify husbands and wives as equal partners. Elder Renlund teaches a righteous husband ministers, praises, and respects, blessing the family as in 'The Family: A Proclamation to the World'.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That transforms how we read it. So the Fall's opposition even shapes eternal families. David, tracing this pattern from Eden to Lehi to us—agency requires opposition for joy.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Precisely. 2 Nephi 2:19-25 shows without misery, no happiness; without Fall, no redemption. Adam and Eve's choice opened the plan of salvation.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: This changes how I see my daily struggles—they're part of progression. What can we learn from Adam and Eve's gladness for today?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Apply Moses 5:9-12: they knew sin, but also righteousness through Christ. Like them, we can choose right amid opposition, offering willing sacrifices.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly, and pray as in Moses 5:4,8 to stay close to God. David, this week's study resolves the Fall mystery beautifully.

script.speaker: David
script.text: It does. Focus not on paradise lost, but glory gained through Christ. Here's the invitation: as you read Genesis 3 and Moses 4-5, ask why the Fall matters to your life.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, complete sentences like 'Because of the Fall, I ... but because of Jesus Christ, I ...' Share your discoveries. Thanks, David—this was profound.

script.speaker: David
script.text: My pleasure, Sarah. Listeners, dive in and find your own joy of redemption.
